meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for <kanji>language</kanji> and you have an imported word, aka a <vocabulary>borrowed word</vocabulary>. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sad</kanji> and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to be sad about</vocabulary> something. Boohoo.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rejoice</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rejoice</vocabulary>. Though <vocabulary>to become happy</vocabulary> probably sounds a little more natural.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>cure</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to cure</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to ease</vocabulary> something. This particular verb is when someone does the curing. The illness or injury doesn't just get better by itself. How can you remember that? Because when you try to heal someone and you mess up, they can try to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you.

Remember how 紀元後 is "Common Era", or "anno Domini"? Well, this is the opposite because it has <kanji>before</kanji> (前) instead of 後. It's <vocabulary>Before the Common Era</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Before Christ</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat in the morning. That is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary>.

You've seen that 泣く is to cry, so you can probably guess that 泣き is just "cry." You've also seen how 虫 is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a <vocabulary>crybaby</vocabulary>?
A <kanji>cry</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound of <vocabulary>crying</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>sob</vocabulary>. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
The <kanji>night</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at night. That is <vocabulary>dinner</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious <vocabulary>lunch</vocabulary>.

You know that お願い means "a request," and 事 can mean "thing." Well, a request for some specific thing can also be called <vocabulary>one's wish</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>. Do you have any 願い事 in your heart right now? Of course you do! Don't worry, you can tell me.

Get <kanji>connected</kanji> to <kanji>west</kanji> Japan by going to <vocabulary>Kansai</vocabulary>! 

関西 is a region in western Japan that includes cities like Osaka, Kyoto, and Kobe. To get to West Japan, you have to pass through (or over) it, so you can think of it as the geographical beginning of western Japan.
The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right side</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left side</vocabulary>. Simple as that.
The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>outside</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji>s is <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>. Which side? Both sides.

両側 typically refers to both sides in a physical sense, like saying there are houses on both sides of the street or handrails on both sides of a staircase.
The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>east side</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the <vocabulary>military personnel</vocabulary>. It also shows the amount of <vocabulary>military strength</vocabulary> an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has!

The <kanji>container</kanji>s that <kanji>soldier</kanji>s use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>weapons</vocabulary>. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is still just another <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>.

Remember how 米国 is "America." Well, more of that again. With 米 representing "America" you can combine that with 兵 (<kanji>soldier</kanji>) to have yourself a <vocabulary>US soldier</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>American soldier</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first <vocabulary>cause</vocabulary> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!

The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> of everything is the <vocabulary>atom</vocabulary>. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
The <kanji>original</kanji> thing you <kanji>make</kanji> is the <vocabulary>original work</vocabulary>. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main cause</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>primary cause</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>hall</kanji> is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a <vocabulary>cafeteria</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>dining hall</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>diner</vocabulary>?
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Water</kanji> with <kanji>salt</kanji> in it is <vocabulary>salt water</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>salty water</vocabulary>.

Unlike "salt water" in English, which often suggests seawater, 塩水 refers to any water that contains some salt in it, including seawater, salt water for gargling, and medical saline.

The <kanji>salt</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is a <vocabulary>salty taste</vocabulary>.

塩味 specifically refers to the <vocabulary>saltiness</vocabulary> found in foods or drinks. It's commonly used in cooking to describe a dish's flavor profile or on food packaging to indicate that the item has a <vocabulary>salty flavor</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Government</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (aka money) is what makes up <vocabulary>government funds</vocabulary>.

Someone from the <kanji>outside</kanji> who comes in to <kanji>mix</kanji> with the <kanji>government</kanji> is a <vocabulary>diplomat</vocabulary>. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do!

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>guess</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary>. Alternatively, you can learn this as <vocabulary>to sense</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to presume</vocabulary>.

Okay, so you <kanji>guess</kanji> but you also kind of <kanji>know</kanji>. You can make an <vocabulary>inference</vocabulary> as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When a <kanji>seat</kanji> is <kanji>lack</kanji>ing the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an <vocabulary>absence</vocabulary>. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.

The people who <kanji>exit</kanji> their <kanji>seat</kanji>s at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true <vocabulary>attendance</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an <vocabulary>empty seat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>open seat</vocabulary>.

The particle に here is a clue that this word is an adverb. An adverb describes actions, so what's a <kanji>normal</kanji> action? It's one you're <vocabulary>always</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>constantly</vocabulary>, doing. That's what makes it normal!
<kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>s are what you have in your regular <vocabulary>everyday life</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>normal life</vocabulary>.
<kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>discerning</kanji> is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are <vocabulary>common sense</vocabulary>.

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>.

Remember how 天気 is weather (and how 天 often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have <vocabulary>dry weather</vocabulary>.

Note that 干天 is quite old-fashioned and you'll find it mainly in formal writing and advanced set expressions.

When you're <kanji>ford</kanji>ing a stream, and you suddenly feel <kanji>dry</kanji> feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary>. It's an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary> trying to stop you from fording.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add <vocabulary>phantom</vocabulary> to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>s.
An <kanji>illusion</kanji> you have when you're <kanji>awake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hallucination</vocabulary>.

An <kanji>illusion</kanji> that you <kanji>imagine</kanji> is your big <vocabulary>fantasy</vocabulary> (it's also an <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when you imagine it, it becomes your fantasy!
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bottom of one's heart</vocabulary>. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from 心底? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>river bottom</vocabulary>, also known as the <vocabulary>riverbed</vocabulary>.

When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> you also have <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.

The <kanji>fault</kanji> of <kanji>romance</kanji> isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unrequited love</vocabulary>. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
When you have <kanji>love</kanji> for your <kanji>country</kanji> deep within your <kanji>heart</kanji>, that is <vocabulary>patriotism</vocabulary>.

When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> and <kanji>love</kanji> all in the same package. Well, that is <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."

If you <kanji>love</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> that is <vocabulary>self love</vocabulary>. You’ll mostly see this word as part of the set phrase ご自愛下さい, which is used in emails and the like to remind the recipients to be good to themselves. Other variations include ご自愛くださいませ, ご自愛を, and ご自愛のほどを.
<kanji>Gender</kanji> <kanji>love</kanji> is that kind of love that has to do with gender parts. That's <vocabulary>sexual love</vocabulary>.

The <kanji>Love</kanji> <kanji>Know</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is <vocabulary>Aichi Prefecture</vocabulary> (jump to the reading to figure this out).

This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>defeat</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary>, but also <vocabulary>to be unsuccessful</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>fault</kanji> and a <kanji>failure</kanji>, all in one. This must have been one big <vocabulary>failure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> you've made.
You have <kanji>win</kanji> and you have <kanji>defeat</kanji>. When you are talking about both in one word, you have <vocabulary>victory or defeat</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>defeat</kanji>ed <kanji>someone</kanji> is the <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the defeated</vocabulary>.

<kanji>Absolutely</kanji> an <kanji>injustice</kanji>! We must <vocabulary>absolutely</vocabulary> punish the perpetrator, <vocabulary>by all means</vocabulary>. First, though, we should probably define <vocabulary>right and wrong</vocabulary>.

This word means "absolutely" when it's used as an adverb, and that's the use you'll hear most in conversation. However, as a noun it means "right and wrong", as in whether something is right or wrong, or good or bad.
A <kanji>fruit</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is just <vocabulary>fruit</vocabulary>.

You <kanji>tie</kanji> up all the <kanji>fruit</kanji> because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> of the big monkey election.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

<kanji>Alcohol</kanji> that comes from <kanji>ume</kanji> is <vocabulary>ume wine</vocabulary>. It can also be called <vocabulary>plum wine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>plum liquor</vocabulary>. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!

When you <kanji>ford</kanji> into the thick of things and <kanji>mix</kanji> everything up, you're getting involved in a <vocabulary>negotiation</vocabulary>. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties.
When your <kanji>power</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> you are <vocabulary>powerless</vocabulary>.

If <kanji>rest</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> then there are <vocabulary>no holidays</vocabulary>. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is <vocabulary>always open</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary>.
Someone with "<kanji>nothing</kanji>" for their <kanji>name</kanji> is either trying to remain <vocabulary>anonymous</vocabulary> or is simply <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is an occurrence where nothing happens to you, or at least nothing too bad — that means you're <vocabulary>safe and sound</vocabulary>. Phew! 

In addition to meaning <vocabulary>safe</vocabulary>, 無事 can also describe a situation where everything goes off <vocabulary>without a hitch</vocabulary>.
When you <kanji>know</kanji> <kanji>nothing</kanji> (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is <vocabulary>ignorance</vocabulary>, it's being <vocabulary>ignorant</vocabulary>.

Imagine having <kanji>nothing</kanji> but <kanji>tea</kanji> for an entire week. Sounds completely <vocabulary>irrational</vocabulary>, right? Such a <vocabulary>reckless</vocabulary> diet plan seems <vocabulary>excessive</vocabulary>.

無茶 is often used to point out that something goes against common sense; or to criticize or disapprove of some actions or situations that might be seen as reckless or excessive.
When the <kanji>fee</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> it is <vocabulary>free</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without charge</vocabulary>!

This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thin</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>, though it can be <vocabulary>slender</vocabulary> as well.

If you <kanji>tie</kanji> the <kanji>bureau</kanji> up with your delays this may not get done this year <vocabulary>after all</vocabulary>.

This word carries the nuance that despite the various events or factors leading up to it, the final outcome just is what it is.

When you write your <kanji>name</kanji> for a <kanji>government office</kanji>, they require you to write out your <vocabulary>signature</vocabulary>. Printing won't do for official government office business.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
People who <kanji>study</kanji> about <kanji>medicine</kanji> are studying the <vocabulary>study of pharmacy</vocabulary>.

These <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s are of the bad kind, they're <vocabulary>drugs</vocabulary>!

As a standalone word, 薬物 generally refers to (often) illegal drugs that cause addiction or have a stimulating effect. Depending on the context, it can also refer to pharmaceutical drugs (aka <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>), but in that case, it's usually used in compounds like 薬物アレルギー (drug allergy).
Something that's <kanji>use</kanji>d for <kanji>medicine</kanji> is <vocabulary>medicinal</vocabulary>.

You know how we use <kanji>feeling</kanji>s to <kanji>memorize</kanji> things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary>s, because feelings are memorized best when you use <vocabulary>the senses</vocabulary>. This can also refer to any particular <vocabulary>sensation</vocabulary> or even somebody's <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary> of humor or fashion!

When you make your <kanji>theory</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with a great <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> for it. Before, it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you gave your explanation, it became bright and easy to understand! Yay!

説明 is a general, everyday word that is used when explaining something unknown or unfamiliar to make it understandable. You may see it when explaining how to use a device or describing a situation, for example.
A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a <vocabulary>novel</vocabulary>?

When people <kanji>transmit</kanji> a <kanji>theory</kanji> through the ages, it can turn into a <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>legendary story</vocabulary>. Kind of like how the "theory" of King Arthur's sword turned into the legend of Excalibur.

A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a <vocabulary>hypothesis</vocabulary>.

This word is generally used when referring to research or some sort of investigation where a hypothesis is put forward that needs to be tested and validated through evidence and experimentation.

A <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is an <vocabulary>illustration</vocabulary> that is used as an <vocabulary>explanatory diagram</vocabulary>. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
You're <kanji>discerning</kanji> about what you <kanji>know</kanji>. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your <vocabulary>knowledge</vocabulary>.

Your <kanji>idea</kanji>s while <kanji>discerning</kanji> things show your <vocabulary>consciousness</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>awareness</vocabulary> of your surroundings. You not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.

意識 is often used in relation to whether someone has consciousness or not, like in medical contexts or news stories. In other contexts it can refer to being aware of certain things, like a high awareness of environmental issues.
They <kanji>warn</kanji> you and they <kanji>guess</kanji> when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the <vocabulary>police</vocabulary>.

When an <kanji>injustice</kanji> to what's <kanji>normal</kanji> is being committed, that makes it an <vocabulary>emergency</vocabulary>! 

Although it's less common, this can also be used as a な adjective. In that case, it means <vocabulary>extreme</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary>.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

If you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the bad words first. This isn't a bad word, but it sort of contains one. くそ means "sh*t" (as in "poop") in Japanese. What is your <kanji>nose</kanji> sh*t, then? It's your <vocabulary>snot</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>boogers</vocabulary>. Eww, stop eating them!

You know the <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>nose</kanji>? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the <vocabulary>tip of the nose</vocabulary>. Time to cut off the rest, next!
Try singing a <kanji>nose</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji>. How does it sound? Like <vocabulary>humming</vocabulary> perhaps?
A <kanji>nose</kanji> with <kanji>blood</kanji> is a nose with a <vocabulary>nosebleed</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>bloody nose</vocabulary>.

Remember how 証明 means "proof"? Well, when you <kanji>write</kanji> the proof down on something, you have a <vocabulary>certificate</vocabulary>.

This can be used for different kinds of <vocabulary>written proof</vocabulary>, like a 卒業証明書 (graduation certificate), 身分証明書 (personal ID), and more.

書く means "to write" and 直す means "to fix," right? Well, if you write something and then decide to fix it, you're going to have <vocabulary>to rewrite</vocabulary> it. Yup, the only way to fix that horrible chicken scratch paragraph you've written is to totally rewrite it from the ground up, so you'd better start rewriting ASAP.
A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>soldier</kanji> is a soldier that is out to sea. In other words, a <vocabulary>navy sailor</vocabulary>.
This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>detailed</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary>.
Things that are <kanji>detailed</kanji> and... <kanji>detailed</kanji> are, well, the <vocabulary>details</vocabulary>.

Something is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>detailed</kanji> at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary> entity. It's <vocabulary>unidentified</vocabulary>.

The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (<vocabulary>drama</vocabulary>). Can also mean <vocabulary>play</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>show</vocabulary> as well.

<kanji>Rejoice</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji> isn't so much drama as it is <vocabulary>comedy</vocabulary>, since it makes you rejoice.

喜劇 is a relatively formal word that refers to comedy in a more traditional or stage-theater sense. For general comedies, people often say お笑い or コメディ.
A <kanji>sad</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji> always ends in <vocabulary>tragedy</vocabulary>. That's what makes it sad.
Something that is <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji> is <vocabulary>dramatic</vocabulary>.
A <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is where people do drama. This is a <vocabulary>theater</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji>. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an <vocabulary>opera</vocabulary>.

歌劇 is a formal word for opera that is typically used in theatrical or artistic contexts. In everyday speech, people usually just say オペラ.

You've seen 美味しい by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of 美 you have 不 (not), so something that does <kanji>not</kanji> have <kanji>flavor</kanji> is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary>. This can also refer to someone who's <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary> at something as well.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

If you can do <kanji>nothing</kanji> within <kanji>reason</kanji>, then what you're trying to do is <vocabulary>unreasonable</vocabulary> and probably downright <vocabulary>impossible</vocabulary>. If you still try, you're probably just <vocabulary>overdoing</vocabulary> it.
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

You've seen how 変える means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, so it means <vocabulary>to be changed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be altered</vocabulary>.

変わる refers to the act of changing into something different, and involves alterations in nature, appearance, or state. For example, it can describe changes in weather or the season, someone undergoing a noticeable change in appearance or behavior, or one's feelings or thoughts evolving over time.

Since 変わる means "becoming something different," you can also use 変わった and 変わっている to describe someone or something that's "different from what's normal." For example, you can say 変わった人 or 変わっている人 to mean "an odd person."
This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>nothing</kanji>, so when you have nothing, you are <vocabulary>without</vocabulary>.
The <kanji>perfect</kanji> way to <kanji>tie</kanji> up a research paper is with a <vocabulary>conclusion</vocabulary>.
When you have <kanji>nothing</kanji> to <kanji>say</kanji> you sit in <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary>.
You know that 愛 means <kanji>love</kanji>. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to love</vocabulary>.

A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working <vocabulary>as usual</vocabulary>. It will be like everything is <vocabulary>the same</vocabulary> as it was before because the change was mutual.
The <kanji>person</kanji> you make <kanji>love</kanji> to is your <vocabulary>lover</vocabulary>. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.

If you tear (てる) up a <kanji>fruit</kanji>, its life is going <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. In other words, the poor thing is going <vocabulary>to die</vocabulary>. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.

Remember how you learned that 昨日 means "yesterday?" Well <kanji>one</kanji> day <kanji>previous</kanji> to that <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day before last</vocabulary>.

The time of <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>spring</kanji> for humans is really just their <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>. Just like plants in spring, your <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary> is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's <vocabulary>the springtime of one's life</vocabulary>.

This generally refers to the period when you’re an energetic teenager and young adult. It can have connotations of exhilarating experiences and bittersweet feelings, as well as nostalgic memories.

Your <kanji>head</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>, or the part of your body that's your head, is… well, your <vocabulary>head</vocabulary>!

This is a more formal way of saying "head" compared to just 頭, so you'll encounter this more frequently in medical and other, more formal contexts.
